segment.source: Customize the Default User Profile by Using CopyProfile
segment.target: Customize the Default User Profile by Using CopyProfile

segment.source: Customize the Default User Profile by Using CopyProfile
segment.target: Customize the Default User Profile by Using CopyProfile

segment.source: Customize the Default User Profile by Using CopyProfile
segment.target: Customize the Default User Profile by Using CopyProfile

segment.source: You can use the setting to customize a user profile and then copy that profile to the default user profile.
segment.target: You can use the setting to customize a user profile and then copy that profile to the default user profile.

segment.source: Windows® uses the default user profile as a template to assign a profile to each new user.
segment.target: Windows® uses the default user profile as a template to assign a profile to each new user.

segment.source: By customizing the default user profile, you can configure settings for all user accounts that are created on the computer.
segment.target: By customizing the default user profile, you can configure settings for all user accounts that are created on the computer.

segment.source: By using , you can customize installed applications, drivers, desktop backgrounds, internet explorer settings, and other configurations.
segment.target: By using , you can customize installed applications, drivers, desktop backgrounds, internet explorer settings, and other configurations.

segment.source: Note that some settings are not preserved by using .
segment.target: Note that some settings are not preserved by using .

segment.source: Enterprise and IT Professionals can use to preserve the customized tile layout of groups on the Start screen.
segment.target: Enterprise and IT Professionals can use to preserve the customized tile layout of groups on the Start screen.

segment.source: In this topic:
segment.target: In this topic:

segment.source: Preserving User Profile Settings
segment.target: Preserving User Profile Settings

segment.target: Configuring Default User Profile Settings

segment.source: Troubleshooting CopyProfile
segment.target: Troubleshooting CopyProfile

segment.source: Creating an answer file with the CopyProfile setting
segment.target: Creating an answer file with the CopyProfile setting

segment.source: Use the following procedure to create an answer file to instruct Sysprep to copy user profile settings when you generalize the Windows image.
segment.target: Use the following procedure to create an answer file to instruct Sysprep to copy user profile settings when you generalize the Windows image.

segment.source: To create a separate answer file for copying user profile settings
segment.target: To create a separate answer file for copying user profile settings

segment.source: On your technician computer, open Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM).
segment.target: On your technician computer, open Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM).

segment.source: Click Start, type Windows System Image Manager, and then select Windows System Image Manager.
segment.target: Click Start, type Windows System Image Manager, and then select Windows System Image Manager.

segment.source: For more information about Windows SIM, see Windows System Image Manager Technical Reference.
segment.target: For more information about Windows SIM, see Windows System Image Manager Technical Reference.

segment.source: Create a new answer file to use with Sysprep:
segment.target: Create a new answer file to use with Sysprep:

segment.source: Click File, and then click New Answer File.
segment.target: Click File, and then click New Answer File.

segment.source: An empty answer file appears in the Answer File pane.
segment.target: An empty answer file appears in the Answer File pane.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If the catalog file doesn't appear in the Windows Image pane, follow the instructions in Open a Windows Image or Catalog File.
segment.target: If the catalog file doesn't appear in the Windows Image pane, follow the instructions in Open a Windows Image or Catalog File.

segment.source: In the Windows Image pane, expand Components, right-click amd64Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup, and then click Add Setting to Pass 4 specialize.
segment.target: In the Windows Image pane, expand Components, right-click amd64Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup, and then click Add Setting to Pass 4 specialize.

segment.source: In the Answer File pane, select the Components4specializeamd64-Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setupneutral folder.
segment.target: In the Answer File pane, select the Components4specializeamd64-Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setupneutral folder.

segment.source: In the Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup Properties pane, in the Settings section, type the value .
segment.target: In the Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup Properties pane, in the Settings section, type the value .

segment.source: Save this new answer file to the root directory of the removable media or network location, and name it CopyProfile.
segment.target: Save this new answer file to the root directory of the removable media or network location, and name it CopyProfile.

segment.source: For more information, see Best Practices for Authoring Answer Files and Unattended Windows Setup Reference Guide.
segment.target: For more information, see Best Practices for Authoring Answer Files and Unattended Windows Setup Reference Guide.

segment.source: Configuring Default User Profile Settings
segment.target: Configuring Default User Profile Settings

segment.source: Use the following procedure to configure user settings in audit mode and then generalize the Windows installation by using an answer file that contains the setting.
segment.target: Use the following procedure to configure user settings in audit mode and then generalize the Windows installation by using an answer file that contains the setting.

segment.source: If you install Windows with another answer file, that answer file should not contain the setting or any settings that create additional user accounts.
segment.target: If you install Windows with another answer file, that answer file should not contain the setting or any settings that create additional user accounts.

segment.source: To configure default user profile settings and generalize the image
segment.target: To configure default user profile settings and generalize the image

segment.source: Install Windows on a reference computer and boot in audit mode.
segment.target: Install Windows on a reference computer and boot in audit mode.

segment.source: For more information, see Boot Windows to Audit Mode or OOBE.
segment.target: For more information, see Boot Windows to Audit Mode or OOBE.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Don't use a domain account, because the setting runs after the computer is removed from the domain when you run Sysprep.
segment.target: Don't use a domain account, because the setting runs after the computer is removed from the domain when you run Sysprep.

segment.source: As a result, you'll lose any settings that you configured in a domain.
segment.target: As a result, you'll lose any settings that you configured in a domain.

segment.source: If you change the default user profile and then join the computer to a domain, the customizations that you made to the default user profile will appear on new domain accounts.
segment.target: If you change the default user profile and then join the computer to a domain, the customizations that you made to the default user profile will appear on new domain accounts.

segment.source: Customize the built-in administrator account by installing applications, desktop shortcuts, and other settings.
segment.target: Customize the built-in administrator account by installing applications, desktop shortcuts, and other settings.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: There is a limit to the number of provisioned Windows Runtime-based apps that you can install.
segment.target: There is a limit to the number of provisioned Windows Runtime-based apps that you can install.

segment.source: However you can create scripts to install additional non-provisioned apps.
segment.target: However you can create scripts to install additional non-provisioned apps.

segment.source: For more information, see Sideload Apps with DISM.
segment.target: For more information, see Sideload Apps with DISM.

segment.source: After your customizations are completed, insert the media that contains the CopyProfile answer file in the reference computer.
segment.target: After your customizations are completed, insert the media that contains the CopyProfile answer file in the reference computer.

segment.source: For example, you can copy the answer file to a USB drive.
segment.target: For example, you can copy the answer file to a USB drive.

segment.source: On the reference computer, open an elevated command prompt, and then type this command:
segment.target: On the reference computer, open an elevated command prompt, and then type this command:

segment.source: where F is the letter of the USB flash drive or other removable media.
segment.target: where F is the letter of the USB flash drive or other removable media.

segment.source: The Sysprep tool removes computer-specific information from the image, while preserving the user profile settings that you configured.
segment.target: The Sysprep tool removes computer-specific information from the image, while preserving the user profile settings that you configured.

segment.source: For more information, see Sysprep (Generalize) a Windows installation.
segment.target: For more information, see Sysprep (Generalize) a Windows installation.

segment.source: After the image is generalized, the computer shuts down, capture the image by booting to Windows PE and then capture the Windows installation by using DISM.
segment.target: After the image is generalized, the computer shuts down, capture the image by booting to Windows PE and then capture the Windows installation by using DISM.

segment.source: For more information, see WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive and Capture Images of Hard Disk Partitions Using DISM.
segment.target: For more information, see WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive and Capture Images of Hard Disk Partitions Using DISM.

segment.source: After the image is captured, you can deploy it to a destination computer by using DISM.
segment.target: After the image is captured, you can deploy it to a destination computer by using DISM.

segment.source: For more information, see Apply Images Using DISM.
segment.target: For more information, see Apply Images Using DISM.

segment.source: Test the User Profile Customizations
segment.target: Test the User Profile Customizations

segment.source: After the customized image is deployed to a destination computer, you can test the user profile customizations.
segment.target: After the customized image is deployed to a destination computer, you can test the user profile customizations.

segment.source: You can go through Out-Of-Box Experience (OOBE) to test the end user experience, or you can test the user customizations in audit mode.
segment.target: You can go through Out-Of-Box Experience (OOBE) to test the end user experience, or you can test the user customizations in audit mode.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Apps based on the Windows Runtime won't start in audit mode because audit mode uses the built-in administrator account.
segment.target: Apps based on the Windows Runtime won't start in audit mode because audit mode uses the built-in administrator account.

segment.source: To run Windows Runtime-based apps you must modify a registry key before you can validate your Windows installation in audit mode.
segment.target: To run Windows Runtime-based apps you must modify a registry key before you can validate your Windows installation in audit mode.

segment.source: To test the user profile customizations after OOBE
segment.target: To test the user profile customizations after OOBE

segment.source: Install Windows to a test computer.
segment.target: Install Windows to a test computer.

segment.source: After Windows is installed, go through OOBE and specify the computer name, user account name, and other items.
segment.target: After Windows is installed, go through OOBE and specify the computer name, user account name, and other items.

segment.source: After OOBE is complete, the Windows start screen appears.
segment.target: After OOBE is complete, the Windows start screen appears.

segment.source: Log onto the computer with the user account specified during OOBE and verify that your apps and customizations appear.
segment.target: Log onto the computer with the user account specified during OOBE and verify that your apps and customizations appear.

segment.source: To test the user profile customizations in audit mode
segment.target: To test the user profile customizations in audit mode

segment.source: Boot to audit mode by using an answer file or by pressing Ctrl+Shift+F3 when OOBE starts.
segment.target: Boot to audit mode by using an answer file or by pressing Ctrl+Shift+F3 when OOBE starts.

segment.source: For more information, see Boot Windows to Audit Mode or OOBE.
segment.target: For more information, see Boot Windows to Audit Mode or OOBE.

segment.source: Verify that your customizations work as intended.
segment.target: Verify that your customizations work as intended.

segment.source: To test Windows Runtime-based apps, modify the following registry key:
segment.target: To test Windows Runtime-based apps, modify the following registry key:

segment.source: From an elevated command prompt, run Regedit.exe.
segment.target: From an elevated command prompt, run Regedit.exe.

segment.source: Browse to the HKEYLOCALMACHINESOFTWAREMicrosoftWindowsCurrentVersionPoliciesSystemFilterAdministratorToken registry key.
segment.target: Browse to the HKEYLOCALMACHINESOFTWAREMicrosoftWindowsCurrentVersionPoliciesSystemFilterAdministratorToken registry key.

segment.source: Click FilterAdministrationToken, and then type 1 as the value data.
segment.target: Click FilterAdministrationToken, and then type 1 as the value data.

segment.source: Log off from the computer.
segment.target: Log off from the computer.

segment.source: Log back on to the computer, and start the Windows Runtime-based apps to verify that your customizations work as intended.
segment.target: Log back on to the computer, and start the Windows Runtime-based apps to verify that your customizations work as intended.

segment.source: After you complete validation of your Windows Runtime-based apps, reset the FilterAdministrationToken registry key to 0.
segment.target: After you complete validation of your Windows Runtime-based apps, reset the FilterAdministrationToken registry key to 0.

segment.source: Troubleshooting CopyProfile
segment.target: Troubleshooting CopyProfile

segment.source: If the user profile settings aren't successfully copied:
segment.target: If the user profile settings aren't successfully copied:

segment.source: Make sure that you set the setting only once during the deployment process.
segment.target: Make sure that you set the setting only once during the deployment process.

segment.source: When you customize user settings, only use only the built-in administrator account on the computer to avoid accidentally copying settings from the wrong profile.
segment.target: When you customize user settings, only use only the built-in administrator account on the computer to avoid accidentally copying settings from the wrong profile.

segment.source: Confirm that you didn't use a domain account.
segment.target: Confirm that you didn't use a domain account.

segment.source: Verify that there are no additional user accounts other than the built-in administrator account that you configured:
segment.target: Verify that there are no additional user accounts other than the built-in administrator account that you configured:

segment.source: Click Start, and then type Control Panel.
segment.target: Click Start, and then type Control Panel.

segment.source: Click Control Panel, and then click Add or remove user accounts.
segment.target: Click Control Panel, and then click Add or remove user accounts.

segment.source: Select any additional user account other than the built-in administrator account that you configured, and then delete it.
segment.target: Select any additional user account other than the built-in administrator account that you configured, and then delete it.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Delete all other user accounts on the computer before you customize the built-in administrator account.
segment.target: Delete all other user accounts on the computer before you customize the built-in administrator account.

segment.source: Make sure that non-provisioned Windows Runtime-based apps that are stored in the tile layout are installed within two hours of user logon to preserve the tile layout on the Start screen, when apps are registered after the new user first logs on.
segment.target: Make sure that non-provisioned Windows Runtime-based apps that are stored in the tile layout are installed within two hours of user logon to preserve the tile layout on the Start screen, when apps are registered after the new user first logs on.

segment.source: Some settings can be configured only by using the unattend setting, and other settings can be configured by using Group Policy.
segment.target: Some settings can be configured only by using the unattend setting, and other settings can be configured by using Group Policy.

segment.source: Use Group Policy to configure settings that are reset by the new user logon process.
segment.target: Use Group Policy to configure settings that are reset by the new user logon process.

segment.source: You can also create scripts to define these user settings.
segment.target: You can also create scripts to define these user settings.

segment.source: -or-
segment.target: -or-

segment.source: Use the unattend setting instead.
segment.target: Use the unattend setting instead.

segment.source: For more information, see Unattended Windows Setup Reference.
segment.target: For more information, see Unattended Windows Setup Reference.
